comments.body:
The tests for this started failing once I enabled `strictNullChecks`, so I fixed it to make the tests work.

On a side note, the tests are still failing for me with a different error now. But the error seems unrelated to my changes, and I also get the same error on DefinitelyTyped:master (which excludes my changes). The error is: Error: ENOTDIR: not a directory, scandir '/home/travis/build/aj-r/DefinitelyTyped/types/tslint.json'.

This feels a bit hacky, so I'm open to input on this one. This was the only way I could make my `let value: any` test pass. The issue is that without this line, typescript will use this overload: ` isArrayLike<any>(value: T | Function): value is any`. And if the function returns false, typescript says that `value` is now type `never`, which is wrong.
Once we get [sutraction types](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/4183) this should become a lot easier.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +12064,12068 @@         * // => false
         */
        isArrayLike<T>(value: T & string & number): boolean; // should only match if T = any
    
        /**

comments.body:
In general, type assertions should be explicit. So instead of

```ts
const p: Person = _.zipObjectDeep(["name", "age"], ["Joe", 32]);
```

it's better to write

```ts
const p = _.zipObjectDeep(["name", "age"], ["Joe", 32]) as Person;
```
@aj-r Do you insist on using `any`? If so I'll change it, but I don't feel like it's the right choice.

According to the [common mistakes](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/master/README.md#common-mistakes), it looks like you are right - we should be forcing people to use a type assertion. So I guess `object` is ok.

This seems like an odd choice if `T1` and `T2` are not comparable (e.g. when `comparator` is `undefined`). I would recommend you leave the original overload and add this one with both `values` and `comparator` as required, otherwise the entire method is much less type safe.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +829,833 @@         * // => [{ 'x': 2, 'y': 1 }]
         */
        differenceWith<T1, T2>(
            array: List<T1> | null | undefined,
            values: List<T2>,

comments.body: How can this take `undefined` as input but return a defined output?
The type will still be wrong because `_.pick(undefined, ["x"])` will not have an `x` property. It would make sense to only accept `undefined` in the second overload that returns `Partial`.
I'm not understanding the `index - not used in this overload` comments. If it's not used, why have it? Could you provide an example of how it's used?
If `guard` is present, lodash ignores the second parameter. Lodash does this so `rangeRight` can be used as an iteratee for `map` (see my other comment).
Gotcha. This library always throws me for a loop.
